Description: Honeywell International Inc. pleaded guilty in federal district court in Benton, Ill., to one felony offense for knowingly storing hazardous waste without a permit in violation of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA). Honeywell was also sentenced to pay a criminal fine in the amount of $11.8 million.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: A settlement with Honeywell International Inc. estimated to be worth more than $10 million will ensure that cleanup of the remaining areas of the Allied Chemical and Ironton Coke Superfund Site in Ironton, Ohio, will move forward, the Justice Department and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Honeywell Resins and Chemicals LLC agreed to pay a $3 million civil penalty for alleged Clean Air Act violations at its Hopewell, Va., plant, and improve the facility's air pollution control equipment and processes. In addition to the $3 million civil penalty, Honeywell agreed to reduce harmful air pollutants, install selective catalytic reduction at four production trains at the facility, conduct a third-party benzene waste operations audit, and implement an enhanced leak detection and repair program at the facility.  Honeywell also agreed to perform a mitigation project valued at approximately $1 million at the facility. The settlement reduced annual emissions of NOx by about 6,260 tons, and cut annual emissions of benzene, other VOCs and hazardous air pollutants by 100 tons.  The estimated cost for injunctive relief to address these emissions was approximately $66 million.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Company: Hoosier Energy Rural Electric Cooperative Inc.
Description: Hoosier Energy Rural Electric Cooperative Inc., an Indiana electric generation and transmission cooperative, agreed to install state-of-the-art pollution control technology at its two coal-fired power plants in Indiana. The settlement required Hoosier to pay a civil penalty of $950,000 and spend $5 million on environmental mitigation projects.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Matson acquired Horizon Lines in 2015
Description: Horizon Lines, LLC was sentenced Tuesday in front of the Honorable Richard Seeborg after pleading guilty to felony charges concerning violations of international and national oil pollution laws that occurred on a large container ship called the S/S Horizon Enterprise, United States Attorney Melinda Haag announced. As part of a plea agreement, the company was ordered to pay $1,500,000, with $500,000 of the monies going to environmental projects in the San Francisco Bay area.

HOVENSA LLC agreed to pay a $5.375 million civil penalty and spend more than $700 million in new pollution controls to resolve Clean Air Act violations at its St. Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands, refinery.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: The Hunt Refining Co. and Hunt Southland Refining Co. agreed to pay a $400,000 civil penalty and spend more than $48.5 million for new and upgraded pollution controls at three refineries.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a with the automakers Hyundai and Kia to resolve alleged Clean Air Act violations based on their sale of close to 1.2 million vehicles that will emit approximately 4.75 million metric tons of greenhouse gases in excess of what the automakers certified to EPA. The automakers agreed to pay a $100 million civil penalty to resolve violations concerning the testing and certification of vehicles sold in America and spend approximately $50 million on measures to prevent any future violations.  Hyundai and Kia also agreed to forfeit 4.75 million greenhouse gas emission credits that the companies previously claimed, which are estimated to be worth over $200 million.  (The Justice Department did not provide a breakdown of the penalties between the two companies. Estimates by Automotive News were used to divided the civil penalty and the cost of the forfeited credits, while the cost of the $50 million in spending to prevent future violations is divided evenly here. The Automotive News article can be found at http://www.autonews.com/article/20141103/OEM11/141109980/hyundai-kia-agree-to-$350m-u.s.-settlement-over-inflated-mileage
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: IBP Inc., then the world's largest meatpacker, agreed to pay the United States $4.1 million in penalties for violating environmental laws and spend an estimated $10 million to construct additional wastewater treatment systems and other environmental controls at its Dakota City, Nebraska plant .
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The former and current owners and operators of a chemical facility in Addyston, Ohio, LANXESS Corp. and INEOS ABS USA Corp., agreed to pay a $3.1 million civil penalty and INEOS will spend up to $2 million to install environmental controls and modify operating procedures to resolve violations of multiple environmental laws.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Interstate Power and Light, a subsidiary of Alliant Energy
Description: Interstate Power and Light agreed to install pollution control technology and meet stringent emission rates to reduce harmful air pollution from the company's seven coal-fired power plants in Iowa. The settlement also required the company to spend a total of $6 million on environmental mitigation projects and pay a civil penalty of $1.1 million to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act. Linn County, Iowa, the state of Iowa and the Sierra Club join the United States as co-plaintiffs in the case.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: International Petroleum Corporation of Delaware was sentenced by United States District Court Judge Gregory M. Sleet to a $1,300,000 fine and $2,200,000 restitution to the City of Wilmington for environmental crimes, including a conspiracy to violate the Clean Water Act.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Invista agreed to pay a $1.7 million civil penalty and spend up to an estimated $500 million to correct self-reported environmental violations discovered at facilities in seven states. The company disclosed more than 680 violations of water, air, hazardous waste, emergency planning and preparedness, and pesticide regulations to EPA after auditing 12 facilities it acquired from DuPont in 2004.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Jenn Feng Industrial Company and MTD Products
Description: A Taiwanese manufacturer and its U.S. distributor agreed to pay a $2 million civil penalty for allegedly selling approximately 200,000 chainsaws in the U.S. that failed to meet federal air pollution standards. The companies also agreed to spend approximately $5 million on projects to reduce air pollution.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Johnson Matthey Inc. was sentenced to a $3 million criminal fine for a felony violation of the Clean Water Act after admitting to violating the Clean Water Act at its Salt Lake City precious metals refining facility.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: A private, Mississippi-based utility company operating sewage treatment and drinking water plants in six states pleaded guilty to a conspiracy related to its failure to give Louisiana residents basic sewage treatment. Johnson Properties Inc. and six subsidiaries agreed to pay a criminal fine of $4.36 million and restitution of $165,000 to affected communities.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The Department of Justice and the Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with the J.R. Simplot Company that resolved alleged Clean Air Act violations related to modifications made at Simplot's five sulfuric acid plants near Lathrop, California, Pocatello, Idaho, and Rock Springs, Wyoming. Under the settlement, Simplot agreed to spend an estimated $42 million on pollution controls that will significantly cut sulfur dioxide emissions at all five plants and fund a wood stove replacement project in the area surrounding the Lathrop plant.

Jupiter Aluminum agreed to take steps to ensure future compliance with certain provisions of the federal Clean Air Act and pay a civil penalty of $2 million, which was to be shared between the United States and the Hammond Department of Environmental Management.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Notes: Note: This penalty is a duplicate of an amount shown in another record (either because it applies to a multi-location settlement or because Violation Tracker contains an agency record and a settlement announcement for the same case).

Description: Kennecott Utah Copper Corporation agreed to implement a comprehensive cleanup of groundwater contamination from past mining operations related to the Bingham Canyon Mine located southwest of Salt Lake City. The work was expected to cost $15 million and take over four decades to complete. Under the terms of the settlement, Kennecott also agreed to pay over $5 million for costs associated with prior investigations and other actions by EPA at the site and surrounding areas.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Kentucky Utilities, a coal-fired electric utility,  agreed to pay a $1.4 million civil penalty and spend approximately $135 million on pollution controls to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Justice announce that Kentucky Utilities Company will spend $57 million to install a sulfuric acid mist emission control system, replace a coal-fired boiler, and pay a civil penalty of $300,000 to resolve alleged Clean Air Act violations (CAA) at the Ghent Station facility in Ghent, Kentucky.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Occidental bought Anadarko in 2019
Description: Kerr-McGee Corp. agreed to spend $18 million on pollution controls as part of a Clean Air Act settlement covering facilities across Utah and Colorado. In addition to implementing pollution controls, the agreement required Kerr-McGee to pay a $200,000 penalty and spend $250,000 on environmental projects to benefit the areas in which the violations occurred.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Kie-Con, Inc., a Delaware corporation, pled guilty in front of the Honorable Nathanael M. Cousins to one count of negligently violating the Clean Water Act and was sentenced to pay $5 million and enter into a comprehensive environmental compliance plan, United States Attorney Melinda Haag announced.

Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, and SFPP, agreed to pay nearly $5.3 million to resolve liability under the Clean Water Act, Oil Pollution Act, Endangered Species Act, and California's Porter-Cologne Water Quality Control Act and Oil Spill Prevention and Response Act, for three oil spills in 2004 and 2005.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: King Pharmaceuticals LLC (King) will pay $2.2 million and take measures to comply with the Clean Air Act to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act (CAA) at its pharmaceutical manufacturing facility located in Bristol, Tenn., announced the Department of Justice, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and the Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation (TDEC).
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: On October 12, 2016, four Texas companies pleaded guilty and agreed to pay a total of $3.5 million for criminal violations of the Clean Air Act at two oil and chemical processing facilities in Texas.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: To resolve claims related to more than 300 oil spills from its pipelines and oil facilities in six states, Koch Industries, Inc. agreed to pay a $30 million civil penalty, improve its leak-prevention programs, and spend $5 million on environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: To settle a Clean Air Act case, Koch agreed to spend an estimated $80 million to install up-to-date pollution-control equipment at two refineries in Corpus Christi, Tex. and one near St. Paul, Minn., reducing emissions from stacks, leaking valves, wastewater vents and flares. Koch also agreed to pay a $4.5 million penalty.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: In a plea agreement in case involving criminal violations of the Clean Air Act, Koch was to pay a total of $20 million: $10 million in criminal fines and $10 million for special projects to improve the environment in Corpus Christi. The plea agreement also required that Koch successfully complete a five-year term of probation and adhere to a strict new environmental compliance program.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Koppers agreed to pay a penalty of $2.9 million to resolve allegations of numerous violations of several environmental regulations at many of the company's U.S. facilities and committed to carry out an environmental management system.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Kroy Corporation, a Florida corporation with its principal place of business in Miami, was sentenced on charges related to smuggling of ozone-depleting substances into the U.S., contrary to the provisions of the Clean Air Act, Title 42, United States Code, Sections 7413(c)(1) and 7671d, in violation of Title 18, United States Code, Section 545. Kroy Corporation was sentenced to five years of probation and a criminal fine of $40,000 and was ordered to forfeit $1,356,160 to the United States.

Company: KTX Limited and KTX Properties Inc.
Description: KTX Limited and KTX Properties Inc. agreed to pay $3.5 million to settle criminal Clean Air Act charges that they negligently released hazardous air pollutants after a tank explosion at their chemical and petroleum processing facility located in Port Arthur, Texas on March 31, 2011. The explosion killed one worker at the plant and severely injured two others.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: LaFarge merged with Holcim in 2015 to form LaFargeHolcim, now known as Holcim Group.
Description: Lafarge North America Inc., based in Herndon, Va., and two of its subsidiaries have agreed in a consent decree filed in federal court in Benton, Ill., to install and implement control technologies at an expected cost of up to $170 million to reduce emissions of NOx by more than 9,000 tons each year and SO2 by more than 26,000 tons per year at their cement plants. In addition, as part of the settlement, Lafarge has agreed to pay a $5 million civil penalty to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act's new source review regulations.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: LaFarge merged with Holcim in 2015 to form LaFargeHolcim, now known as Holcim Group.
Description: Lafarge North America Inc., one of the largest suppliers of construction materials in the United States and Canada, and four of its U.S. subsidiaries have agreed to resolve alleged Clean Water Act violations. The violations include unpermitted discharges of stormwater and failure to comply with stormwater permits at 21 stone, gravel, sand, asphalt and ready-mix concrete facilities in Alabama, Colorado, Georgia, Maryland and New York.Stormwater flowing over concrete manufacturing facilities can carry debris, sediment and pollutants including pesticides, petroleum products, chemicals and solvents, which can have a significant impact on water quality. Lafarge will implement a nationwide evaluation and compliance program at 189 of its similar facilities in the United States to ensure they meet Clean Water Act requirements. Lafarge will also pay a penalty of $740,000 and implement two supplemental environmental projects, in which the company will complete conservation easements to protect approximately 166 acres in Maryland and Colorado. The U.S. estimates that Lafarge will spend approximately $8 million over five years to develop and maintain this compliance program.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: LaFarge merged with Holcim in 2015 to form LaFargeHolcim, now known as Holcim Group.
Description: Under an agreement announced with U.S Environmental Protection Agency, the U.S. Department of Justice and New York State, Lafarge North America Inc. has agreed to fund $1.5 million in projects to reduce air pollution in the community surrounding its Ravena, New York cement plant.

Lagoon Landing, LLC was sentenced in federal court in the Northern District of Florida for illegal dredging and felony wetlands violations and sentenced to a term of probation of three years, a fine of $2.15 million, a community service payment of $1 million to the National Fish and Wildlife foundation, a charitable non-profit organization created by Congress, and a $400 special monetary assessment.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Delek acquired majority interest in Lion Oil from Ergon in 2011.
Description: To resolve a Clean Air Act case, Lion Oil agreed to spend $21.5 million to reduce emissions, pay a $348,000 civil penalty and spend $450,000 on supplementary environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Lockheed Martin Corporation and subsidiaries Lockheed Martin Energy Systems and Lockheed Martin Utility Services agreed to pay $5 million to resolve allegations that they violated the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act and, in misrepresenting their compliance with RCRA to the Department of Energy, knowingly submitted false claims for payment under their contracts with DOE to operate the Paducah Gaseous Diffusion Plant in Paducah, Kentucky.

Recap of Ownership Changes: NRG sold Louisiana Generating to Cleco, a subsidiary of Macquarie, in 2018
Description: Louisiana Generating, an electric generating company owned by NRG Energy Inc., agreed to a settlement at its Big Cajun II coal-fired power plant in New Roads, La., which will result in the elimination of over 27,300 tons of harmful emissions per year. The settlement, lodged in federal court in Baton Rouge, will require Louisiana Generating to spend approximately $250 million to reduce air pollution and also requires the company to pay a civil fine of $3.5 million and spend $10.5 million on environmental mitigation projects.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Mitsubishi sold Lucite to Midorikawa Chemical in 2022
Description: The Justice Department and the Environmental Protection Agency reached a Clean Air Act settlement with Lucite International, Inc. requiring the chemical manufacturer to install pollution controls costing an estimated $16 million on three emission sources at its Memphis, Tennessee plant in addition to paying a civil penalty of $1.8 million and performing a supplemental environmental project worth $1.3 million.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Lumber Liquidators changed its name to LL Flooring in 2020.
Description: Virginia-based hardwood flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators Inc. was sentenced in federal court in Norfolk, Virginia to pay more than $13 million in criminal fines, community service and forfeited assets related to its illegal importation of hardwood flooring, much of which was manufactured in China from timber that had been illegally logged in far eastern Russia.

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2021 Medline was acquired by a consortium of private equity firms.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Company: E.I. Du Pont de Nemours and Company
Recap of Ownership Changes: This facility was among those included in the 2015 spinoff of DuPont operations as Chemours
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Notes: This facility is one of those transferred from DuPont to its Chemours spinoff in 2015.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Oneok bought Magellan in 2023.
Description: A pipeline company and two of its former operating firms agreed to jointly pay a civil penalty of $3.65 million to resolve violations of the Clean Water Act resulting from anhydrous ammonia spills in Nebraska and Kansas. The spills, which occurred in 2004, resulted in significant fish kills in surrounding waterways.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Oneok bought Magellan in 2023.
Description: Magellan Midstream Partners agreed to pay a $5.3 million civil penalty for alleged violations of the Clean Water Act, including discharges of gasoline and fuel oil from pipelines in Illinois, Kansas, Iowa, Minnesota and Arkansas into nearby waterways over the past 10 years.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Oneok bought Magellan in 2023.
Description: The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with Magellan Pipeline Company, L.P., for alleged violations of the Clean Water Act related to gasoline, diesel and jet fuel spills in Texas City, Texas, Nemaha, Neb. and El Dorado, Kan. Magellan agreed to complete approximately $16 million of injunctive relief across its 11,000-mile pipeline system and pay a $2 million civil penalty.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Cal-Maine bought Mahard in 2019
Description: Mahard Egg Farm Inc., a Texas corporation operating in both Texas and Oklahoma, has agreed to pay a $1.9 million penalty to resolve claims that the company failed to comply with the Clean Water Act at its egg production facilities, announced the Department of Justice and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The civil penalty is the largest ever to be paid in a federal enforcement action involving a concentrated animal feeding operation (CAFO), and is in addition to approximately $3.5 million that Mahard will spend on remedial measures to bring the company into compliance with the law and protect the environment and people's health.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Marathon Ashland was included in the properties that were spun off as Marathon Petroleum in 2011
Description: To resolve a Clean Air Act case, the company agreed to spend $265 million to reduce emissions, pay a $3.8 million civil penalty and spend $6.5 million on supplementary environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Justice announced an agreement with Marathon Petroleum Company to reduce air pollution from the company's petroleum refineries in Illinois, Kentucky, Louisiana, Michigan and Ohio.  Marathon agreed to spend $319 million to install state-of-the-art Flare Gas Recovery Systems, which will capture and recycle gases that would otherwise be sent to combustion devices known as flares.  Marathon also agreed to spend $15.55 million on projects to reduce air pollution at three of the facilities and pay a civil penalty of $326,500 to the United States.

The Department of Justice and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced a settlement with Marathon Petroleum Corporation that resolved various alleged Clean Air Act violations at ten Marathon facilities and requires Marathon to take steps to reduce harmful air pollution emissions at facilities in three states. The Department of Justice and EPA alleged that Marathon failed to comply with certain Clean Air Act fuel quality emissions standards and recordkeeping, sampling and testing requirements. These violations may have resulted in excess emissions of air pollutants from motor vehicles, which can pose threats to public health and the environment. Marathon self-reported many of these issues to EPA. Under a consent decree lodged in U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, Marathon agreed to spend over $2.8 million on pollution controls to reduce emissions of volatile organic compounds on 14 fuel storage tanks at its distribution terminals in Indiana, Kentucky and Ohio. Marathon was also required to pay a $2.9 million civil penalty and retire 5.5 billion sulfur credits, which had a current market value of $200,000.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Company: Marine Shale Processors Inc. and Recycling Park Inc.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Alpha, then known as Alpha Natural Resources, bought Massey in 2011
Description: Massey Energy Company, Inc. agreed to pay a $20 million civil penalty in a corporate-wide settlement to resolve Clean Water Act violations at coal mines in West Virginia and Kentucky.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: MBK Partnership, an Oregon general partnership of local real estate developers, entered into a consent decree to resolve a long-running dispute involving homeowners in Klamath Falls, Oregon who alleged that the homes they purchased from MBK were contaminated with asbestos. MBK, its partners, and their insurers agreed to pay approximately $11 million in compensation and litigation costs.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: McWane Inc., a national cast iron pipe manufacturer headquartered in Birmingham, Ala., agreed to resolve more than 400 violations of federal and state environmental law at 28 of its manufacturing facilities in 14 states as part of a settlement filed in federal court and announced by the Justice Department, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, and the states of Alabama and Iowa.

In a case involving criminal violations of the Clean Water Act, McWane was sentenced to pay a fine of $5 million, serve a period of probation for five years and ordered to perform a community service project valued at $2.7 million.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Cast-iron pipe manufacturer McWane, Inc. pleaded guilty to environmental crimes in connection with the operation of Pacific States Cast Iron Pipe Company. Specifically, McWane pleaded guilty to two counts of submitting a document to the State of Utah containing falsified emission test results. McWane was ordered to pay a $3 million fine and to serve a three-year period of probation.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Clean Water Act
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Merck resolved alleged violations of federal and state water pollution control regulations by agreeing to pay $10 million to put into place systems that will prevent future dangerous discharges at their facility andl spend approximately $9 million for extensive environmental projects.  The consent decree also required Merck to pay $750,000 in federal penalties and damages plus $750,000 to the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and $75,000 to the Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Justice announced that Merck & Co. agreed to pay a $1.5 million civil penalty to settle alleged violations of federal environmental laws at its pharmaceutical manufacturing facilities in Riverside and West Point, Pa.

To settle a Clean Air Act case at a natural gas facility, owner Merit Energy and former owner Shell Exploration agreed to pay a penalty of $500,000; Merit also agreed to spend $1 million on an environmental project.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Notes: Note: This penalty is a duplicate of an amount shown in another record (either because it applies to a multi-location settlement or because Violation Tracker contains an agency record and a settlement announcement for the same case).

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Justice announced a $3.5 million Clean Air Act settlement with Meyer's Bakery, headquartered in Little Rock, Ark.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: MGP Ingredients of Illinois, Inc. (MGP)--an ethanol producing company--reached a settlement to resolve claims that it violated the Clean Air Act by spending about $1.5 million on pollution controls and paying an $85,900 penalty to the federal government.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and Peugeot SA merged to become Stellantis in 2021.
Description: The Department of Justice, the EPA and the State of California announced a settlement with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles N.V., FCA US, and affiliates for alleged violations of the Clean Air Act and California law. Fiat Chrysler agreed to implement a recall program to repair more than 100,000 noncompliant diesel vehicles sold or leased in the United States, offer an extended warranty on repaired vehicles, and pay a civil penalty of $305 million to settle claims of cheating emission tests and failing to disclose unlawful defeat devices. Fiat Chrysler also agreed to implement a program to mitigate excess pollution from these vehicles.  The recall and federal mitigation programs were estimated to cost up to approximately $185 million. In a separate settlement with California, Fiat Chrysler agreed to pay an additional $19 million to mitigate excess emissions from more than 13,000 of the noncompliant vehicles in California. In addition, in a separate administrative agreement with the United States Customs and Border Protection, Fiat Chrysler agreed to  pay a $6 million civil penalty to resolve allegations of illegally importing 1,700 noncompliant vehicles.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Michigan Sugar, a grower-owned sugar cooperative located in Bay City, Mich., agreed to install pollution reduction measures valued at more than $13 million at its processing facility to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act. Michigan Sugar also agreed to pay a $210,000 civil penalty.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Mid-Valley Pipeline Company and  Sunoco Pipeline L.P.
Recap of Ownership Changes: Sunoco merged with Energy Transfer in 2012
Description: The federal government today reached a settlement with Mid-Valley Pipeline Company and pipeline operator Sunoco Pipeline L.P. requiring the companies to pay a $2.57 million penalty--including $1.4 million to the federal government--relating to a January 2005 spill that dumped more than 260,000 gallons of crude oil into the Kentucky and Ohio Rivers.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) personnel conducted an inspection of the Mid-Continent Fractionation and Storage facility in Conway, Kan., in April 2012. As a result of the inspection, Mid-Continent has agreed to spend approximately $2 million to construct and operate a system to reduce emissions of volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors to the atmosphere.

The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a final settlement with Millard Refrigerated Services that resolved alleged violations of the Clean Air Act, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act and Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act violations for an airborne release of ammonia from Millard's Theodore, Alabama, facility in 2010. Millard agreed to pay a $3 million penalty for the violations that sickened 152 people responding to the BP oil spill.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: In a settlement with the United States, Minnesota Power (MP), an ALLETE company based in Duluth, Minnesota agreed to install pollution control technology and meet stringent emission rates to reduce harmful air pollution from the company's three coal-fired power plants located in Cohasset, Hoyt Lakes and Schroeder, Minnesota. The settlement resolved claims that the company violated the New Source Review provisions of the Clean Air Act by unlawfully constructing major modifications at its plants without obtaining required permits and installing and operating the best available air pollution control technology. The settlement also required that the company pay a civil penalty of $1.4 million to resolve Clean Air Act violations and spend at least $4.2 million on environmental projects to benefit local communities. The state of Minnesota was co-plaintiff to the settlement and was to receive $200,000 of the penalty.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Company: Minnkota Power Cooperative and Square Butte Electric Cooperative
Description: The two cooperatives agreed to spend more than $100 million on pollution control equipment to resolve a Clean Air Act case.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Mobil Oil Guam Inc. and Mobil Oil Mariana Islands Inc.
Description: Two subsidiaries of Exxon Mobil Corporation - Mobil Oil Guam Inc. and Mobil Oil Mariana Islands Inc. - have agreed to pay $2.4 million for allegedly violating the federal Clean Air Act by failing to control emissions from their facilities, the Justice Department and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced today.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Company: Mobil Exploration and Producing U.S. Inc
Description: Mobil Exploration settled allegations relating to oil spills on Navajo Nation land by agreeing to spend $4.7 million on field operation improvements, pay a $515,000 civil penalty and spend $327,000 on a supplementary environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: MOEX Offshore 2007 LLC agreed to settle its liability in the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in a settlement with the United States valued at $90 million. Approximately $45 million of the $90 million settlement was in the form of penalties or expedited environmental projects.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Bayer acquired Monsanto in 2018.
Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced that Monsanto Company Inc., of St. Louis, Missouri, has agreed to pay a $2.5 million penalty to resolve misbranding violations related to the sale and distribution of cotton seed products containing genetically engineered pesticides. This is the largest civil administrative penalty settlement ever received under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA).

Recap of Ownership Changes: Dow Chemical sold Morton to K+S Group when it acquired Rohm and Haas in 2009. K+S sold the business to Stone Canyon in 2021.
Description: Morton International Inc. agreed to pay a civil penalty of $20 million and a criminal penalty of $2 million to resolve charges the chemical company violated several environmental laws at its Moss Point, Miss.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2004 IMC Global merged with Cargill's fertilizer business to form Mosaic. Cargill controlled a majority of Mosaic until 2011.
Description: Mosaic Fertilizer agreed to spend approximately $30 million on air pollution controls to eliminate harmful emissions from its sulfuric acid production plant in Uncle Sam, Louisiana. The company also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $2.4 million to resolve alleged Clean Air Act violations.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) announced a settlement with Mosaic Fertilizer, LLC tol ensure the proper treatment, storage, and disposal of an estimated 60 billion pounds of hazardous waste at six Mosaic facilities in Florida and two in Louisiana.Under the settlement, Mosaic Fertilizer agreed to establish a $630 million trust fund, which would be invested until it reached full funding of $1.8 billion. Mosaic also agreed to also spend $170 million on projects to reduce the environmental impact of manufacturing and waste management programs at its facilities and $2.2 million on two local environmental projects. It also agreed to pay a $5 million civil penalty to the United States and $1.55 million to the State of Louisiana and $1.45 million to the State of Florida, who joined EPA and DOJ as plaintiffs in this case.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Saudi Aramco, former 50-50 joint venture owner with Royal Dutch Shell, took full ownership in 2017
Description: To resolve a Clean Air Act case, Motiva Enterprises LLC, Equilon Enterprises LLC, and Deer Park Refining Limited Partnership, which jointly operated nine oil refineries, agreed to spend $400 million to reduce emissions, pay a $9.5 million civil penalty and spend $5.5 million on supplementary environmental projects. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally between the three.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: MotorScience Inc., and MotorScience Enterprise Inc.
Description: Two Los Angeles-based consulting firms, MotorScience Inc., and MotorScience Enterprise Inc., (MotorScience) and their owner, Chi Zheng, have agreed to settle alleged Clean Air Act (CAA) violations stemming from the illegal import of 24,478 all-terrain, recreational vehicles into the U.S. from China without testing to ensure emissions would meet applicable limits on harmful air pollution, announced the Department of Justice, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Air Resources Board (ARB). MotorScience and Zheng have agreed to have a stipulated judgment entered against them for a $3.55 million civil penalty and to pay an additional $60,000 civil penalty within six months.  The United States will receive 80 percent of collected penalties, and California will receive the remaining 20 percent.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Murphy Oil spun off its retail business as Murphy USA in 2013
Description: Murphy Oil USA agreed to spend more than $142 million to install new and upgraded pollution reduction equipment at its two petroleum refineries in Wisconsin and Louisiana as part of a comprehensive Clean Air Act settlement. The settlement also required Murphy to pay a $1.25 million civil penalty and spend an additional $1.5 million on a supplemental environmental project.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Murphy Oil spun off its retail business as Murphy USA in 2013
Description: The Justice Department, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Wisconsin Department of Justice announced a settlement with Murphy Oil USA, Inc. under which the company agreed to spend $7.5 million to cut sulfur dioxide emissions from its Superior, Wisconsin refinery and pay a $5.5 million civil penalty.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The National Cooperative Refinery Association (NCRA) has agreed to pay $700,000 in penalties to the United States and the State of Kansas, and perform a series of injunctive relief actions, to settle violations of federal environmental laws and the Kansas State Implementation Plan at its petroleum refinery and underground storage facility in McPherson County, Kan.

Company: Navajo Refining Company and Montana Refining Company
Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2011 Holly merged with Frontier Oil to form HollyFrontier. In 2022 HollyFrontier merged with Sinclair Oil to form HF Sinclair.
Description: To resolve a Clean Air Act case, the companies, then subsidiaries of Holly Corp., agreed to spend up to $21 million to reduce emissions, pay a $750,000 civil penalty and spend $1.5 million on supplementary environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2013 Nevada Power was acquired by MidAmerican Energy, a subsidiary of Berkshire Hathaway
Description: Nevada Power Company agreed to a joint settlement today with the federal government and the state of Nevada that will require the utility to spend nearly $85 million on cleaner technology, pay a $1.11 million fine, and spend $4 million on energy conservation projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2013 Nevada Power was acquired by MidAmerican Energy, a subsidiary of Berkshire Hathaway
Description: The Department of Justice and the Environmental Protection Agency announced a $60.7 million Clean Air Act settlement with Nevada Power Company designed to improve air quality in the Clark County/Las Vegas area by requiring the company to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides from its Clark Generating Station. The company was to spend $60 million on pollution control equipment and $400,000 on an environmental mitigation project in addition to a civil penalty of $300,000.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and New Cingular Wireless (NCW) have reached an administrative settlement requiring the company to pay a civil penalty of $750,000 and spend $625,000 on environmental projects to resolve alleged reporting, planning and permitting violations at 332 legacy AT&T Wireless (AWS) sites now owned by NCW.

Recap of Ownership Changes: New Mountain bought Zep in 2015
Description: Acuity Specialty Products, Inc., a company with a manufacturing plant in Atlanta pleaded guilty to a one-count information charging it with a knowing violation of the Clean Water Act. Per the terms of the plea agreement, a federal judge imposed a sentence of three years of probation and a fine of $3.8 million.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Chevron bought Noble in 2020
Description: A settlement was reached with Houston-based Noble Energy, Inc. to resolve alleged Clean Air Act violations stemming from the company's oil and gas exploration and production activities in the Denver-Julesburg Basin, north of Denver, Colorado. The settlement resolved claims that Noble failed to adequately design, size, operate and maintain vapor control systems on its controlled condensate storage tanks, resulting in emissions of volatile organic compounds. As part of the settlement, Noble agreed to spend an estimated $60 million on system upgrades, monitoring and inspections to reduce emissions, in addition to $4.5 million to fund environmental mitigation projects, $4 million on supplemental environmental projects and a $4.95 million civil penalty.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Norfolk Southern Railway Company agreed to pay a $4 million penalty to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Water Act (CWA) and hazardous materials laws for a 2005 chlorine spill in Graniteville, S.C.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Northern Indiana Public Service Co. (NIPSCO) signed a settlement agreement in which it has agreed to invest approximately $600 million in pollution control technology to resolve violations of the Clean Air Act. The proposed settlement covers all of NIPSCO's coal fired power plants, located in Chesterton, Michigan City, Wheatfield and Gary, Ind. It will require that NIPSCO spend $9.5 million on environmental mitigation projects and pay a civil penalty of $3.5 million. The state of Indiana has been involved with developing this settlement and is a signatory.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: To settle a Clean Air Act case, Nucor agreed to spend $85 million on new emission controls, pay a $9 million civil penalty and spend $4 million on emission monitoring.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Oceanfleet Shipping Limited and Oceanic Illsabe Limited
Description: Two Greek shipping companies were sentenced to pay corporate penalties totaling $2.7 million after being convicted for obstructing justice, violating the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS), tampering with witnesses and conspiracy.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: As part of a Clean Air Act settlement, Ohio Edison agreed to spend $1.1 billion on pollution control equipment, pay a civil penalty of $8.5 million and spend $25 million on other environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The Justice Department, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and state of Washington announced that a civil settlement with Olympic Pipe Line Company and Shell Pipeline Company LP for environmental violations leading to the 1999 fatal pipeline rupture. Olympic agreed to pay a $2.5 million federal penalty and spend $15 million on a spill prevention program.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Cooke bought Omega in 2017
Description: Omega was charged with violations of the CWA and Oil Pollution Act {33 U.S.C. 1319(c)(2)(A) - knowingly discharging a pollution, in violation of 33 U.S.C. 1311; and 33 U.S.C. 1321(b)(3) - knowingly discharging oil}. Omega pled guilty to the charges and was sentenced to 36 months probation and ordered to pay $5.5 million in federal fines and $2 million in court ordered fines, totaling $7.5M.

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2019 Owen-Illinois changed the name of its parent company to O-I Glass
Description: Ohio-based Owens-Brockway Glass Container Inc., the nation's largest glass container manufacturer, agreed to install pollution control equipment to reduce harmful emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur dioxide (SO2) and particulate matter (PM) by nearly 2,500 tons per year and pay a $1.45 million penalty to resolve alleged Clean Air Act violations at five of the company's manufacturing plants. The pollution controls required as part of the settlement to reduce NOx, SO2, and PM were said to cost an estimated $37.5 million.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: P4 Production was a subsidiary of Monsanto. Bayer acquired Monsanto in 2018.
Description: The Department of Justice and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced that P4 Production LLC, a mining and phosphorus processing company wholly-owned by Monsanto and operating near Soda Springs in southeast Idaho, agreed to pay a $1.4 million civil penalty for alleged Clean Water Act violations at its South Rasmussen Mine. In addition to the penalty, P4 agreed to spend an estimated $875,000 on monitoring and to prevent pollutants from entering local waters.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Patriot Coal Corporation agreed to pay a $6.5 million civil penalty to settle alleged violations of the Clean Water Act.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Valero sold the refinery to PBF in 2010
Description: In 2005 Premcor Refining, then the owner of the Delaware City Refinery, agreed to spend $7.5 million on improved environmental controls. At the same time, Motiva Enterprises, which owned the facility at the time of a catastrophic explosion in 2001, agreed to pay a $12 million civil penalty, spend $4 million on supplementary environmental projects and reimburse public agencies for $170,000 in response costs. The refinery was later sold to PBF Energy.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: PCS Nitrogen Fertilizer, AA Sulfuric Inc., and White Springs Agricultural Chemicals Inc.
Recap of Ownership Changes: Nutrien was formed through the merger of Agrium and PotashCorp in 2018
Description: In a settlement with the United States, three subsidiaries of the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan (PCS), the worlds largest fertilizer producer, will take steps to reduce harmful air emissions at eight U.S. production plants. The settlement resolved claims that these PCS subsidiaries violated the Clean Air Act when they modified facilities in ways that released excess sulfur dioxide into surrounding communities. The settlement required PCS Nitrogen Fertilizer, AA Sulfuric Inc., and White Springs Agricultural Chemicals Inc. to install, upgrade and operate state-of-the-art pollution reduction measures, as well as install emissions monitors at eight sulfuric acid plants across facilities in Geismar, Louisiana (one plant), White Springs, Florida (four plants), and Aurora, North Carolina (three plants).  The three companies were required to spend an estimated $50 million on these measures and pay a $1.3 million civil penalty.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Pelican Refining Company LLC, was sentenced to pay $12 million for felony violations of the Clean Air Act and obstruction of justice charges in federal court in Lafayette, Louisiana.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Travis County District Attorney Rosemary Lehmberg announced that Pemco Services, Inc. was convicted of Texas Water Code violations relating to the operation of an oil and gas waste landfarming site in Jefferson County, Texas. The District Attorney's Environmental Protection Unit prosecuted the case. Judge Mike Lynch ordered Pemco Services, Inc. to pay fines totaling $1,350,000.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Icahn Enterprises acquired Pep Boys in 2016
Description: The Pep Boys - Manny, Moe & Jack - agreed to pay $5 million in civil penalties and take corrective measures to settle claims that it violated the Clean Air Act by importing and selling motorcycles, recreational vehicles and generators manufactured in China that do not comply with environmental requirements.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Freeport bought Phelps in 2007
Description: Phelps Dodge Sierrita, Inc. agreed to pay $1.4 million--of which $1.36 million was to go to the federal government and the rest to the state of Arizona--for allegedly violating the federal Clean Air Act at a facility in Arizona.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: This property was among the businesses spun off as Phillips 66 in 2012.
Description: As part of a Clean Air Act settlement, ConocoPhillips agreed to spend $525 million on new emissions control equipment, pay a $4.5 million civil penalty and spend $10 million on supplementary environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: This property was among the businesses spun off as Phillips 66 in 2012.
Description: The Department of Justice, the Environmental Protection Agency and the United States Attorney's Office announced the settlement of claims against ConocoPhillips Company and Sasol North America Inc. to resolve their liability to EPA under CERCLA for contamination in the Calcasieu Estuary of Louisiana. The Justice Department also announced a settlement of claims for natural resource damages against ConocoPhillips Company and Sasol North America Inc. related to contamination in the Estuary. Under the terms of a consent decree lodged in the federal district court for the Western District of Louisiana together with a filed complaint, ConocoPhillips and Sasol North America will reimburse the EPA Superfund more than $4.5 million and will complete a removal action valued at about $10 million to clean up Bayou Verdine within the Calcasieu Estuary. The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality (LDEQ) is also a plaintiff in the case and party to the settlement. (The Justice Department did not specify how the costs would be divided between the two companies. Here we assume they were split equally.)
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Plains All American Pipeline L.P. and several of its operating subsidiaries agreed to spend approximately $41 million over the next three years to prevent and remediate corrosion, improve leak detection practices and capabilities, and enhance pipeline oversight on 10,420 miles of crude oil pipeline operated in the United States. The settlement resolved Clean Water Act violations arising out of 10 crude oil spills in Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Kansas and also requires the pipeline company to pay a $3.25 million civil penalty.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Plantation Pipe Line Company agreed to pay a civil penalty and implement safeguards in order to resolve a Clean Water Act lawsuit over fuel pipeline spills in three states.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced that Post Holdings, Inc. and Ralcorp Holdings Inc. would pay $635,000 for violations of the federal Clean Air Act, including failing to install required air pollution controls at its cereal production facility located in Modesto, Calif. The penalty was in addition to approximately $1.4 million the company has already spent on equipment necessary to reduce emissions.

The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with the Potomac Electric Power Company (Pepco) for alleged violations of Pepco's Clean Water Act permit at its service center located  in Anacostia.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Company: PowerTrain Inc., Wood Sales Inc., and Tool Mart Inc.
Description: Mississippi-based PowerTrain Inc., Wood Sales Inc., and Tool Mart Inc., (collectively known as PowerTrain) agreed to jointly pay a civil penalty of $2 million to resolve claims that the company imported and sold almost 80,000 nonroad engines and equipment that were not covered by emissions-related certificates of conformity, and in most cases could not be certified because they exceeded emissions standards under the Clean Air Act.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Valero Energy acquired Premcor Refining Group in 2005
Description: Premcor Refining Group, Inc., formerly known as Clark Refining and Marketing, Inc., agreed to pay a $6.25 million penalty to resolve claims that its Blue Island Refinery in Blue Island, Ill. violated five federal statutes: the Clean Water Act, the Clean Air Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act and the Emergency Planning, Community Right-To-Know Act and state of Illinois environmental laws and regulations. Premcor closed the refinery in January 2001.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Premium Standard Farms (PSF) and Continental Grain Company
Recap of Ownership Changes: Smithfield was acquired by WH Group in 2013.
Description: To resolve a Clean Water Act case, the companies agreed to spend an estimated $50 million on new waste treatment technology and pay a civil penalty of $350,000.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: To resolve a Clean Air Act case, the company agreed to spend $337 million to reduce emissions, pay a $1.4 million civil penalty and spend $6 million on supplementary environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Justice announced a Clean Air Act settlement with PSEG Fossil LLC related to the company's failure to comply with a 2002 consent decree requiring installation of pollution controls at its coal-fired power plants in Jersey City and Hamilton, N.J. This new settlement included a $4.25 million payment to the federal government as well as additional air pollution reductions and tighter controls.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Public Service Company of New Mexico
Description: EPA and the Department of Justice announced consent decree with Arizona Public Service Company, Southern California Edison, El Paso Electric Company, Public Service Company of New Mexico, Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District, and Tucson Electric Power Company. (The consent decree did not specificy how the $1.5 million civil penalty is to be divided among the defendants. Here we assume it is equally divided as $300,00 to each of the five corporate defendants. That amount is added to the costs --which are specified--of the projects the companies are required to fund.)

Recap of Ownership Changes: Diamondback Energy acquired QEP Resources in 2021.
Description: The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with QEP Field Services Co., formerly Questar Gas Management Co., to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act at five natural gas compressor stations on the Uintah and Ouray Reservation in Northeastern Utah. Four members of the Ute Indian Tribe intervened as co-plaintiffs. Under the proposed settlement, QEPFS will pay a $3.65 million civil penalty and pay $350,000 into a Tribal Clean Air Trust Fund to be established by the tribal member intervenors. The settlement also requires QEPFS to reduce its emissions by removing certain equipment, installing additional pollution controls, and replacing the natural gas powered instrument control systems with compressed air control systems.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Republic Services of Southern Nevada, operator of the Sunrise Mountain Landfill located in Clark County, Nev., agreed to spend an estimated $36 million to on a comprehensive remedy for the site and to pay a $1 million civil fine in order to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Water Act.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Rhodia Inc., an acid manufacturer, agreed to pay a $2 million penalty and spend approximately $50 million on air pollution controls at eight production plants in four states across the country to settle allegations that the company violated the Clean Air Act.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Rhodia Inc. pleaded guilty to two felony violations of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act at an elemental phosphorus manufacturing plant in Silver Bow County, Montana. Pursuant to a plea agreement, Rhodia was required to pay $18 million in criminal fines and restitution and to clean up the site.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Rocky Mountain Pipeline System LLC, Western Convenience Stores Inc. and Offen Petroleum Inc.
Description: Three gasoline distributors agreed to pay $2.5 million to resolve claims that they illegally mixed and distributed more than one million gallons of gasoline that did not meet Clean Air Act emissions and fuel quality requirements.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Roquette America, Inc., agreed to pay a $4.1 million civil penalty to settle alleged violations of the Clean Water Act and its National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit at its grain processing facility in Keokuk, Iowa.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Ensco merged with Rowan Cos. to form Valaris in 2019.
Description: Rowan Companies, Inc. pleaded guilty to three felonies in connection with the routine discharge of pollutants and garbage into the Gulf of Mexico from one of the firm's oil rigs. Rowan was required to pay a $7 million criminal fine, along with community service payments totaling $1 million to five state government enforcement organizations and a community service payment of $1 million to the National Marine Sanctuaries Foundation.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Ardagh bought Saint-Gobain containers in 2014
Description: Saint-Gobain Containers Inc. of Muncie, Ind., agreed, in a consent decree filed in federal court in Seattle, to install pollution control equipment at an estimated cost of $112 million to reduce emissions of NOx, SO2 and PM by approximately 6,000 tons each year. The settlement covered 15 plants in 13 states. Two of the 15 plants had been closed by Saint-Gobain for independent business reasons. In addition, as part of the settlement, Saint-Gobain agreed to pay a $2.25 million civil penalty to resolve its alleged violations of the Clean Air Act's new source review regulations.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Ardagh bought Saint-Gobain containers in 2014
Description: As part of a Clean Air Act settlement, Saint-Gobain Containers, Inc. of Muncie, Indiana agreed to reduce emissions through the installation of approximately $6.6 million worth of new equipment, pay a civil penalty of $929,000 and spend $1.2 million for an environmental project that will also reduce emissions.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District
Description: The owner and operator of a coal-fired power plant in St. Johns, Ariz. agreed to install pollution controls at an estimated cost of $400 million to reduce harmful emissions and pay a $950,000 civil penalty.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2011 Bimbo Bakeries bought Sara Lee's baking business.
Description: To resolve a Clean Air Act case involving the use of ozone-depleting refrigerants, Earthgrains Baking--which was acquired by Sara Lee during the investigation--agreed to pay a civil penalty of $5.25 million and spend $5 million to convert refrigeration equipment.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The Department of Justice, the Environmental Protection Agency and the United States Attorney's Office announced the settlement of claims against ConocoPhillips Company and Sasol North America Inc. to resolve their liability to EPA under CERCLA for contamination in the Calcasieu Estuary of Louisiana. The Justice Department also announced a settlement of claims for natural resource damages against ConocoPhillips Company and Sasol North America Inc. related to contamination in the Estuary. Under the terms of a consent decree lodged in the federal district court for the Western District of Louisiana together with a filed complaint, ConocoPhillips and Sasol North America agreed to reimburse the EPA Superfund more than $4.5 million and will complete a removal action valued at about $10 million to clean up Bayou Verdine within the Calcasieu Estuary. The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality (LDEQ) is also a plaintiff in the case and party to the settlement. (The Justice Department did not specify how the costs would be divided between the two companies. Here we assume they were split equally.)
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: The Scotts Miracle-Gro Company, a producer of pesticides for commercial and consumer lawn and garden uses, was sentenced in federal district court in Columbus, Ohio, to pay a $4 million fine and perform community service for eleven criminal violations of the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA), which governs the manufacture, distribution, and sale of pesticides. Scotts pleaded guilty in February 2012 to illegally applying insecticides to its wild bird food products that are toxic to birds, falsifying pesticide registration documents, distributing pesticides with misleading and unapproved labels and distributing unregistered pesticides. In a separate civil agreement with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Scotts agreed to pay more than $6 million in penalties and spend $2 million on environmental projects under a settlement that resolves additional civil pesticide violations . The violations included distributing or selling unregistered, canceled or misbranded pesticides, including products with inadequate warnings or cautions.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: Sevenson Environmental Services Inc., an environmental remediation firm based in Niagara Falls, New York, agreed to pay more than $2.72 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act and the Anti-Kickback Act by accepting kickbacks, rigging bids and passing inflated charges to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency in connection with work performed at the Federal Creosote Superfund Site in Manville, New Jersey.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Company: Shell Chemical L.P. and Shell Chemical Yabucoa
Recap of Ownership Changes: Royal Dutch Shell changed its name to Shell PLC in 2022
Description: Shell Chemical L.P. and Shell Chemical Yabucoa agreed to install pollution reduction equipment on two petroleum refining facilities at an estimated cost of $6 million as part of two comprehensive Clean Air Act settlements. The two companies agreed to pay a combined $3.3 million civil penalty to the United States as well as Alabama and Louisiana and $200,000 to Louisiana organizations for environmental education and emergency operations.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Royal Dutch Shell changed its name to Shell PLC in 2022
Description: The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced that Shell Oil and affiliated partnerships agreed to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act at a large refinery and chemical plant in Deer Park, Texas, by spending at least $115 million to control harmful air pollution from industrial flares and other processes, and by paying a $2.6 million civil penalty. Shell agreed to spend $1 million on a state-of-the-art system to monitor benzene levels at the fenceline of the refinery and chemical plant near a residential neighborhood and school and to make the data available to the public through a website.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Royal Dutch Shell changed its name to Shell PLC in 2022
Description: The Justice Department, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and state of Washington announced that a civil settlement with Olympic Pipe Line Company and Shell Pipeline Company LP for environmental violations leading to the 1999 fatal pipeline rupture. Shell agreed to pay a $5 million federal penalty and spend $62 million on a spill prevention program.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (PADEP) and the Allegheny County Health Department (ACHD) have reached a settlement with Shenango Inc. (Shenango) resolving alleged air and water pollution violations at the company's coke manufacturing plant on Neville Island, Allegheny County, Pa. The consent decree requires the company to pay $1.75 million in civil penalties and make significant upgrades to the plant, which is located about five miles north of downtown Pittsburgh.

Shintech, Inc. and its subsidiary K-Bin, Inc., agreed to spend $4.8 million to comply with the Clean Air Act and the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act at their manufacturing facilities in Freeport, Texas.  The companies also agreed to pay a $2.585 million civil penalty to resolve environmental violations under the Clean Air Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, and the Clean Water Act, and to perform $4.7 million worth of supplemental environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2022 Sinclair Oil merged with HollyFrontier to form HF Sinclair Corporation.
Description: Sinclair Oil Corp. agreed to pay a $2.45 million civil penalty and spend more than $72 million for new and upgraded pollution controls to reduce air pollution from the company's three refineries in Casper and Sinclair, Wyo., and in Tulsa, Okla.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2022 Sinclair Oil merged with HollyFrontier to form HF Sinclair Corporation.
Description: The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with two subsidiaries of Sinclair Oil Corporation to resolve alleged violations of air pollution limits established in a 2008 consent decree at refineries in Casper and Sinclair, Wyo. Sinclair Casper Refining Co. and Sinclair Wyoming Refining Co. were to pay stipulated penalties totaling $3,844,000 and spend approximately $10.5 million on additional pollution control equipment and other projects to resolve the allegations. The settlement also required the Sinclair companies to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur dioxide (SO2) and particulate matter by approximately 24,385 and 59 tons per year, respectively.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2009 Sinclair sold the business to Holly Corporation, which in 2011 Holly merged with Frontier Oil to form HollyFrontier. In 2022 HollyFrontier merged with Sinclair Oil to form HF Sinclair.
Description: Sinclair Tulsa Refining Company, a subsidiary of major oil and gasoline producer Sinclair Oil, was sentenced to pay a criminal penalty of $5 million and a community service payment of $500,000 for environmental violations at the Tulsa Refinery.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: To resolve a Clean Air Act case, Slawson agreed to spend $4.1 million on system upgrades, monitoring and inspections; spend at least an estimated $2 million to fund environmental mitigation projects; and pay a $2.1 million civil penalty.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Company: South Carolina Public Service Authority (Santee Cooper)
Description: To resolve a Clean Air Act case, Santee Cooper agreed to reduce its emissions, pay a $1.3 million civil penalty to the federal government and spend at least $4.5 million to finance projects that are environmentally beneficial.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: EPA and the Department of Justice announced a consent decree with Arizona Public Service Company, Southern California Edison, El Paso Electric Company, Public Service Company of New Mexico, Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District, and Tucson Electric Power Company. (The consent decree did not specificy how the $1.5 million civil penalty is to be divided among the defendants. Here we assume it is equally divided as $300,00 to each of the five corporate defendants. That amount is added to the costs --which are specified--of the projects the companies are required to fund.)

The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with Southern Coal Corporation and 26 affiliated mining companies that required the companies to make comprehensive upgrades to their coal mining and processing operations to prevent discharges of polluted wastewater from their mines in Appalachia.  The estimated cost of these measures was $5 million. The companies also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $900,000.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Company: Southern Indiana Gas and Electric Company, Inc.
Recap of Ownership Changes: CenterPoint Energy and Vectren merged in 2019
Description: To settle a Clean Air Act case, the company agreed to spend approximately $30 million to reduce emissions, pay a civil penalty of $600,000 and spend at least $2.5 million on an environmental project.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2012 Southern Union was bought by Energy Transfer
Description: Southern Union Company was found guilty of storing hazardous waste (waste liquid mercury) without a permit and sentenced in U.S. District Court in the District of Rhode Island on October 2, 2009, to a $6 million fine, $12 million of community service payments and two years of probation.

To settle a case involving groundwater contamination, the agreed to pay $1 million to the New Mexico Natural Resources Trustee for natural resource damages; a $293,500 penalty to the United States for violating a 1998 cleanup order; $181,500 in civil penalties that will go to the State of New Mexico; and $200,000 in litigation costs to the State of New Mexico and the City of Albuquerque.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Sterling Suffolk Racecourse LLC agreed to pay a civil penalty of $1.25 million to resolve violations of the Clean Water Act (CWA) at its Suffolk Downs racetrack facility in Revere and East Boston, Mass., the U.S. Department of Justice and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced. The company also also agreed to spend more than $3 million to prevent polluted water from entering nearby waterways and will perform three environmental projects worth approximately $742,000 that will provide water quality monitoring and protection efforts for more than 123 square miles of watershed.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: DFA bought Dean Foods in 2020
Description: Suiza Dairy agreed to pay a penalty and make significant upgrades to settle Clean Air Act violations. The case stemmed from violations at two Suiza Dairy Corporation dairies located in Rio Piedras and Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, including two major releases of anhydrous ammonia from the Rio Piedras facility. As part of the consent decree, Suiza agreed to pay a penalty of $275,000 and spend approximately $3.75 million on projects to improve the refrigeration systems at both facilities, considerably reduce the amount of anhydrous ammonia in the systems at both facilities, improve alarm and ammonia release notification procedures, and provide medical training and/or equipment to medical personnel to treat persons affected by exposure to anhydrous ammonia.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: SunCoke Energy Inc. and two of its subsidiaries have agreed to pay $1.995 million to resolve alleged Clean Air Act violations of emission limits at the Gateway Energy and Coke plant in Granite City, Illinois, and the Haverhill Coke plant in Franklin Furnace, Ohio, announced the Justice Department and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: Sunoco merged with Energy Transfer in 2012
Description: At part of a Clean Air Act settlement covering its petroleum refineries, Sunoco agreed to spend about $285 million to install improved emission controls. It also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $3 million and spend $3.9 million on supplementary environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Superior Crude Gathering Inc. (Superior Crude) agreed to pay a civil penalty for alleged violations of the Clean Water Act stemming from a 2010 crude oil spill from tanks at Superior's oil storage facility in Ingleside, Texas. Under the consent decree lodged in federal court, Superior agreed to pay $1.61 million to resolve the governments claims.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Recap of Ownership Changes: ChemChina bought Syngenta in 2017
Description: Syngenta Seeds, Inc.of Golden Valley, Minn., agreed to pay a $1.5 million penalty to EPA for selling and distributing seed corn that contained an unregistered genetically engineered pesticide called Bt 10.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Emera bought TECO in 2016
Description: To settle a Clean Air Act case Tempa Electric agreed to spend $3 million on emission controlks, pay a $3.5 million civil penalty and spend at least $10 million on environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Description: Tanknology-NDE, International, Inc. was sentenced to pay a $1 million criminal fine and restitution of $1.29 million to the United States for false underground storage tank (UST) testing services performed by its employees.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Company: TE Products Pipeline Company, LLC and TEPPCO Crude Pipeline, LLC
Description: TE Products Pipeline Company, LLC and TEPPCO Crude Pipeline, LLC agreed to pay a $2.865 million penalty to resolve violations of the Clean Water Act.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division

Recap of Ownership Changes: Temple-Inland was acquired by International Paper in 2012
Description: Temple was charged with violating the CWA {33 U.S.C. 1319(c)(1)(A) - negligently causing the discharge of a pollutant and violating the Conservation Act 16 U.S.C. 668(c) - negligently taking of fish from the Bogue Chitto National Wildlife Refuge. Temple Inland was sentenced to 24 months probation, ordered to pay a federal fine in the amount of $1.5 million and restitution totaling $1.2 million as follows: $900,000 to the Trust for Public Land, $200,000 to U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and $100,000 to the Nature Conservancy.
